private_information: I have direct knowledge of the initial distribution of disks on the pegs.
Initial configuration: left peg (top->bottom) A, B, C, D, E, F; middle peg empty; right peg empty.
local_controller.goal: Report the exact initial peg contents and disk ordering to the orchestrator.

private_information: I know the legal move rules for the Tower of Hanoi puzzle.
Rules: move only one disk at a time; a larger disk may never be placed on top of a smaller one; only the top disk of a peg may be moved.
validator.goal: Provide a clear, unambiguous specification of the puzzle constraints and invariants to the orchestrator.

private_information: I will combine information from other agents and produce a complete PDDL domain and problem suitable for FastDownwards.
orchestrator.goal: Produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem that, when solved by FastDownwards, yields a valid sequence of moves that transfers all disks from the left peg to the right peg following the rules.

public_information: Puzzle: Tower of Hanoi using three pegs named left, middle, and right.
There are 6 disks labeled A, B, C, D, E, F where A is the smallest and F is the largest.
Legal moves: move one disk at a time, only the top disk of any peg may be moved, and a larger disk cannot be placed on a smaller disk.
Initial configuration: left peg contains disks A (top), B, C, D, E, F (bottom); middle peg empty; right peg empty.
Goal configuration: left peg empty; middle peg empty; right peg contains disks A (top), B, C, D, E, F (bottom).

report_state.system_prompt: You are the local controller responsible for reporting the exact initial arrangement of disks on each peg. Provide a concise structured description of peg contents and the top-to-bottom ordering for each peg.
report_state.prompt: Your name is local_controller. You have the following public information: Puzzle: Tower of Hanoi using three pegs named left, middle, and right. There are 6 disks labeled A, B, C, D, E, F where A is the smallest and F is the largest. Provide the initial peg contents known to you in a clear structured form, specifying for each peg its disks from top to bottom. Do not produce PDDL. Your goal is: Report the exact initial peg contents and disk ordering to the orchestrator.

report_rules.system_prompt: You are the validator whose role is to state the precise legal move constraints and invariants for the Tower of Hanoi instance. Provide these constraints in a structured, unambiguous way that can be translated into planning preconditions and effects.
report_rules.prompt: Your name is validator. You have the following public information: Puzzle: Tower of Hanoi using three pegs named left, middle, and right. There are 6 disks labeled A, B, C, D, E, F where A is the smallest and F is the largest. Provide a precise description of the legal moves, allowed actions, and invariants (for example which disk can move, restrictions about placing disks) that the orchestrator can use to build a planning domain. Do not produce PDDL. Your goal is: Provide a clear, unambiguous specification of the puzzle constraints and invariants to the orchestrator.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in producing PDDL domains and problems for classical planners and specifically target the FastDownwards solver. Using the inputs from other agents, produce a complete PDDL domain and a PDDL problem that encodes the Tower of Hanoi instance. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Ensure types, predicates, actions, initial state, and goal are compatible with standard FastDownwards expectations. Keep agent-provided actions or descriptions distinct if needed. The final output must be ready for FastDownwards.
pddl.prompt: Your name is orchestrator. You will receive structured inputs from other agents describing the initial state and the rules. Use the initial_state_info and rules_info to construct a full PDDL domain and a PDDL problem for the following global goal: Move all disks from the left peg to the right peg so that the right peg holds disks A, B, C, D, E, F from top to bottom and the other pegs are empty. Keep object naming consistent with disk labels A, B, C, D, E, F and peg names left, middle, right. Encode the single-disk-move restriction and the size ordering constraint so that larger disks cannot be placed on smaller disks. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. The PDDL must be complete and suitable for FastDownwards. Think step by step and produce the domain and the problem.
